messageBody:
Consider this a formal poke. ;-)

What file would your obtainMerchant() method live in?

- George

P.S. What appserver are you using? Are you using an IDE? or
writing everything from scratch?


--- In junit@y..., Robert Watkins <robertw@q...> wrote:
> Ralf Krakowski writes:
> > Thanks a lot for your response.
> > Any write up of such a paper would be great since I am new to both
> > JUnit and EJB. Could I help you in any way?
>
> You can poke me every so often so I don't procrastinate. :)
Actually, I've
> collected a lot of material in the last few weeks, and I just need
to polish
> it up a bit. I'm not aiming at formal publication or anything...
just an
> article on junit.org would be the limits of my humble ambition.
>
> > Could you please submit a simple example of a the "smart" function
> > (method :-) you talked about.
>
> Um. Okay.
>
> Here's a sample test method:
> public void testGetMerchantId() throws java.rmi.RemoteException
{
> obtainMerchant("Merchant1");
> assertEquals("Merchant1", getSample().getMerchantId());
> }
>
> Here's a smart implementation of obtainMerchant:
> protected void obtainMerchant(String merchantId) {
> if (EjbHelper.isLive()) {
> try {
> javax.ejb.EJBHome ejbHome =
> EjbHelper.lookupHome(MERCHANT_HOME, MerchantHome.class);
> MerchantHome home = (MerchantHome)ejbHome;
>
> setSample(home.create(merchantId));
> }
> catch (javax.ejb.CreateException e) {
> throw new RuntimeException("CreateException: " +
> e.getMessage());
> }
> catch (javax.naming.NamingException e) {
> throw new RuntimeException("NamingException: " +
> e.getMessage());
> }
> catch (java.rmi.RemoteException e) {
> throw new RuntimeException("RemoteException: " +
> e.getMessage());
> }
> }
> else {
> return new MerchantImpl(merchantId);
> }
> }
>
> (EjbHelper is a utility class, but it should be fairly obvious what
it does,
> from context). About the only thing that's not clear is that
> EjbHelper.isLive() returns Boolean.getBoolean("EJB_LIVE_MODE"),
allowing EJB
> testing to be turned on or off by supplying a system property.
>
> > Any other tips and practical issues regarding testing and EJB
would
> > be great.
>
> I'll see what I can come up with.
>
> > I have heard that this (testing locally and then live) is not
> > nessesary with Visual Age since you can run your appserver within
> > Visual Age...? Is this true?
>
> Technically, this is true, or so I'm told. When I was playing with
EJB 1.0,
> I didn't have Visual Age. When I had Visual Age, I'd moved on to
EJB 1.1,
> which VAJ doesn't support. However, I've got a goal of being able
to run my
> unit tests from the command line, via Ant, so I wouldn't want to
rely on
> such support, anyway (though it would be handy for the odd debugging
> session).
>
> However, VAJ doesn't like more than one person working on an EJB
group (a
> collection of related EJBs) at a time (it will actually end up
corrupting
> the repository, given enough time, and will produce all sorts of
weird side
> effects in the interim). If you're working by yourself, that's not a
> problem. If you're working with others, it's nasty. There's a
review on
> theserverside.com, by Bartek Kiepuszewski (a former co-worker of
mine),
> which details all the hassles we had doing EJB development in VAJ
and
> WebSphere. (http://theserverside.com/reviews/thread.jsp?
thread_id=2974)
>
> Robert.
>
> --
> "Duct tape is like the Force: it has a light side, a dark side,
> and it holds the universe together"
> Robert Watkins robertdw@b... robertw@q...
